comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: #5 is Francisco Ignacio Madero, President of Mexico 1911-1913. The caption says "F. I. Madero" and the photo is a match for the one in the Wikipedia article.

comment.author: 25385374@N04
comment._content:
#3 in the photograph is Venustiano Carranza. 

I haven't heard of the Carrenas name in Mexico, unless it could be Carreñas. Yet, when I saw who the person was, no doubt, his beard and eyeglasses says it all... he is Venustiano Carranza. 

When president Madero (#5 in the photograph) and Pino Suarez are assasinated by Huerta (not in the picture), Venustiano Carranza declares war against Huerta on the inconstitutionality of the coup d'etat. His army was known as the Carrancistas or the Ejercito Constitucionalista (Constitutionalist Army). He also became president but was also assasinated.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: tolteca_pilo: Thank you for the additional information!  We will edit the source data to reflect that #3 appears to be Venustiano Carranza and then reload the description to Flickr.

comment.author: 25385374@N04
comment._content:
After writing my first comment I learned a new fact.

According to Taibo, biographer of Pancho Villa, this is one of two similar photographs. Both are the same, only difference is that Pancho Villa appears in one. No one knows why he dissappeared for the second photo.

comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Person number 12 is given as "Francisco Madero padre". This appears to be the President's father, also Franciso I. Madero, and hence Francisco I. Madero, Sr. See another photograph Senior here: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3121125542/

comment._content: LOC has another photo of Madero and Suarez with other members of the peace commission taken in May, 1911 at Cuidad Juarez. Information here, but no scan.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: Wrote Federico Vázquez Gómez, must be Francisco Vázquez Gomez (he run as vice-presidente under Madero's provisional rule) {number 4 in this picture}.  Wrote Francisco Indalecio Madero (as is comonly known) his birth certificate says Francisco Ignacio Madero González

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: jerodamor: Thank you for identifying Francisco Vázquez Gomez. He does look like the same man whose illustrated portrait appears in this Tacoma Times article from March 13, 1912, (available online through Chronicling America): chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88085187/1912-03-13/ed-... . We'll adjust the description when we next update.

Is Alberto Fuentes (paternal last name), Dávila (maternal last name).
In México paternal last name goes first
